note: Fields: description (layman + clinical), ml (medical language), family, scientificName, usages, activeConstituents, safetyClassification, dosageGuidelines

absinthe herb.description: A bitter aromatic herb used historically in absinthe liqueur. Known medically as a digestive bitter and vermifuge.
absinthe herb.usages: Digestive stimulant, appetite enhancer, anti-parasitic, menstrual regulation
absinthe herb.safetyClassification: Caution - thujone is neurotoxic in high doses; avoid in pregnancy
absinthe herb.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g dried herb per cup, 1-2x daily max. Tincture: 10-20 drops before meals.

acacia.description: A gum-producing tree/shrub. The gum (gum arabic) is used as a demulcent and emulsifier.
acacia.usages: Soothing irritated mucous membranes, binding agent, mild astringent for diarrhea
acacia.safetyClassification: Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) for food use
acacia.dosageGuidelines: Gum: 5-30g daily in divided doses. Powder: 1-5g mixed in water.

activated charcoal.description: Highly porous carbon used to adsorb toxins. Medically used for poisoning and overdose treatment.
activated charcoal.usages: Acute poisoning treatment, gas/bloating relief, water filtration
activated charcoal.activeConstituents: Pure carbon with high surface area
activated charcoal.safetyClassification: Safe for acute use; may interfere with medication absorption
activated charcoal.dosageGuidelines: Poisoning: 50-100g single dose (medical supervision). Gas: 500mg-1g after meals.

adhatoda.description: Also called Malabar nut or Vasaka. A traditional Ayurvedic herb for respiratory conditions.
adhatoda.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy (uterine stimulant); use under practitioner guidance
adhatoda.dosageGuidelines: Leaf juice: 10-20ml. Powder: 1-3g. Decoction: 50-100ml twice daily.

african ginger.description: A rhizomatous plant native to Africa with warming, aromatic properties similar to common ginger.
african ginger.usages: Colds, flu, malaria support, pain relief, digestive aid
african ginger.safetyClassification: Generally safe; limited safety data available
african ginger.dosageGuidelines: Fresh rhizome: 2-5g chewed or decocted. Powder: 1-2g daily.

african pepper.description: Also known as grains of paradise or alligator pepper. A pungent spice with medicinal uses.
african pepper.usages: Digestive aid, warming stimulant, ceremonial use, libido enhancement
african pepper.safetyClassification: Generally safe in culinary amounts; avoid excessive doses in pregnancy
african pepper.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 0.5-2g crushed, taken with food or in decoction.

african potato.description: A tuberous plant used in Southern African traditional medicine for immune support.
african potato.usages: Immune support, prostate health, general tonic
african potato.safetyClassification: Caution with immunosuppressants; may interact with antiretrovirals
african potato.dosageGuidelines: Corm: 1-2g dried powder daily. Decoction: 2-4g boiled in water.

african wormwood.description: A bitter aromatic herb used in African traditional medicine for fevers and digestive complaints.
african wormwood.usages: Fever, colds, flu, intestinal parasites, colic, menstrual pain
african wormwood.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; use short-term only due to thujone content
african wormwood.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g dried leaves per cup, 2-3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml daily.

agave nectar.description: A sweet syrup from agave plants, used as a natural sweetener with lower glycemic index than sugar.
agave nectar.usages: Sweetener, wound healing (traditional), soothing sore throats
agave nectar.safetyClassification: Safe in moderate amounts; high fructose may affect liver if excessive
agave nectar.dosageGuidelines: As sweetener: use sparingly, 1-2 tsp per serving.

agrimony.description: A gentle astringent herb used for digestive and urinary complaints. Known as 'church steeples'.
agrimony.usages: Diarrhea, sore throat gargle, wound healing, liver/gallbladder support
agrimony.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

ajwain.description: Also called carom seeds or bishop's weed. A pungent spice used in Indian cuisine and Ayurveda.
ajwain.safetyClassification: Generally safe in culinary amounts; avoid large doses in pregnancy
ajwain.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-3g chewed or in decoction. Oil: 1-2 drops diluted.

aloe vera.description: A succulent plant with gel used topically for burns and skin, and internally as a laxative.
aloe vera.usages: Burns, wounds, skin hydration, constipation (latex), digestive soothing
aloe vera.safetyClassification: Gel: generally safe. Latex: strong laxative, avoid long-term use
aloe vera.dosageGuidelines: Gel: apply topically; internally 1-2 tbsp. Latex: 50-200mg short-term.

aloe ferox.description: Cape aloe, a South African species with stronger laxative properties than Aloe vera.
aloe ferox.usages: Constipation, skin conditions, bitter digestive tonic
aloe ferox.safetyClassification: Strong laxative - avoid in pregnancy, IBD, children; short-term only
aloe ferox.dosageGuidelines: Dried latex: 50-200mg at bedtime. Gel: topical as needed.

amaranth.description: A nutritious pseudo-cereal and leafy green used for food and traditional medicine.
amaranth.usages: Nutrition, diarrhea, heavy menstrual bleeding, mouth ulcers
amaranth.safetyClassification: Generally safe; contains oxalates - moderate for kidney stone risk
amaranth.dosageGuidelines: Grain: as food. Leaf: as vegetable or tea 2-4g dried.

american ginseng.description: A cooling adaptogenic root native to North America, less stimulating than Asian ginseng.
american ginseng.usages: Stress adaptation, fatigue, blood sugar regulation, immune support
american ginseng.activeConstituents: Ginsenosides (Rb1, Rc, Rd, Re, Rg1), polysaccharides
american ginseng.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with warfarin, diabetes medications

amla.description: Indian gooseberry, one of the richest natural sources of vitamin C. Ayurvedic cornerstone.
amla.usages: Immune support, hair/skin health, digestion, liver protection, anti-aging
amla.activeConstituents: Vitamin C, tannins (emblicanin A/B), gallic acid, ellagic acid
amla.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may enhance bleeding risk with anticoagulants
amla.dosageGuidelines: Fresh fruit: 1-2 daily. Powder: 3-6g daily. Juice: 20-30ml daily.

angelica.description: A tall aromatic herb used in European and Chinese medicine for digestive and respiratory issues.
angelica.usages: Digestive complaints, bronchitis, menstrual regulation, appetite stimulation
angelica.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; photosensitizing - avoid sun after use
angelica.dosageGuidelines: Root: 1-3g as tea or decoction. Tincture: 1-2ml 3x daily.

angelica dahurica.description: A Chinese medicinal herb (Bai Zhi) used for pain, sinus congestion, and skin conditions.
angelica dahurica.usages: Headache, sinus congestion, toothache, skin infections
angelica dahurica.safetyClassification: Photosensitizing; avoid in pregnancy; use under TCM guidance
angelica dahurica.dosageGuidelines: Decoction: 3-10g. Often used in formulas rather than alone.

anise.description: A sweet, licorice-flavored seed used for digestive complaints and respiratory congestion.
anise.usages: Gas, bloating, coughs, bronchitis, promoting milk flow
anise.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid large doses in pregnancy (estrogenic)
anise.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-5g crushed in tea. Essential oil: 1-2 drops diluted.

annatto.description: A natural colorant and traditional medicine from the seeds of the achiote tree.
annatto.usages: Food coloring, blood sugar regulation, skin conditions, fever
annatto.safetyClassification: Generally safe as food colorant; may lower blood sugar
annatto.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-2g in decoction. Leaf tea: 2-4g dried leaves.

apple cider vinegar.description: Fermented apple juice used as a folk remedy for digestion and blood sugar management.
apple cider vinegar.usages: Digestion, blood sugar regulation, weight management, topical antiseptic
apple cider vinegar.activeConstituents: Acetic acid (5-6%), malic acid, polyphenols, probiotics (raw)
apple cider vinegar.safetyClassification: Generally safe diluted; may erode tooth enamel; caution with diabetes meds
apple cider vinegar.dosageGuidelines: 1-2 tbsp diluted in water before meals. Topical: dilute 1:1.

arjuna.description: An Ayurvedic heart tonic from the bark of the Arjuna tree for cardiovascular support.
arjuna.usages: Heart failure, angina, high blood pressure, high cholesterol
arjuna.activeConstituents: Arjunolic acid, arjunic acid, arjungenin, tannins, flavonoids
arjuna.safetyClassification: May interact with cardiac medications; use under supervision
arjuna.dosageGuidelines: Bark powder: 1-3g twice daily. Decoction: 3-6g boiled in water/milk.

arnica.description: A mountain flower used topically for bruises, sprains, and muscle pain. Toxic internally.
arnica.usages: Bruises, sprains, muscle soreness, arthritis (topical only)
arnica.safetyClassification: EXTERNAL USE ONLY - toxic internally; avoid on broken skin
arnica.dosageGuidelines: Topical: creams/gels 10-25% tincture. Homeopathic: as directed.

aronia.description: Chokeberry, a dark berry extremely high in antioxidants for cardiovascular health.
aronia.usages: Cardiovascular health, blood sugar, urinary tract, antioxidant support
aronia.dosageGuidelines: Berries: 100-300g fresh or as juice. Extract: 300-500mg daily.

artemisia annua.description: Sweet wormwood, source of artemisinin used in malaria treatment.
artemisia annua.usages: Malaria, fever, intestinal parasites, bacterial infections
artemisia annua.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may interact with antimalarials; short-term use
artemisia annua.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 5-9g dried herb per liter, divided doses.

asafoetida.description: A pungent resin (hing) used in Indian cooking and Ayurveda for digestive complaints.
asafoetida.activeConstituents: Ferulic acid, umbelliferone, sulfur compounds, resins
asafoetida.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause GI upset in large doses
asafoetida.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 250-500mg with food. Resin: pinch in cooking.

ashoka.description: A sacred tree in Ayurveda, primarily used for women's reproductive health.
ashoka.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; use under guidance for hormonal conditions
ashoka.dosageGuidelines: Bark powder: 3-6g daily. Decoction: 50-100ml twice daily.

ashwagandha.description: Indian ginseng, a premier Ayurvedic adaptogen for stress, energy, and vitality.
ashwagandha.usages: Stress, anxiety, fatigue, insomnia, immune support, male fertility
ashwagandha.activeConstituents: Withanolides (withaferin A, withanolide D), alkaloids, iron
ashwagandha.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy, hyperthyroidism
ashwagandha.dosageGuidelines: Root powder: 3-6g daily. Standardized extract: 300-600mg daily.

astragalus.description: Huang Qi in TCM, a deep immune tonic and energy builder for chronic conditions.
astragalus.usages: Immune deficiency, fatigue, heart health, wound healing
astragalus.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid during acute infections
astragalus.dosageGuidelines: Sliced root: 9-30g in decoction. Extract: 250-500mg 2-3x daily.

atractylodes.description: Bai Zhu in TCM, used to strengthen digestion and dry dampness in the body.
atractylodes.usages: Poor appetite, bloating, diarrhea, edema, fatigue
atractylodes.safetyClassification: Generally safe in TCM formulas; use under guidance
atractylodes.dosageGuidelines: Decoction: 6-12g. Usually combined with other herbs.

ayahuasca vine.description: A sacred Amazonian vine used in traditional shamanic ceremonies. Contains MAO inhibitors.
ayahuasca vine.safetyClassification: CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE; dangerous MAO interactions; requires guidance
ayahuasca vine.dosageGuidelines: Traditional ceremonial use only. Not for self-administration.

bala.description: Country mallow, an Ayurvedic herb for strength, nerve health, and rejuvenation.
bala.usages: Weakness, nerve disorders, heart health, respiratory conditions
bala.safetyClassification: Contains ephedrine - avoid with heart conditions; banned in some countries
bala.dosageGuidelines: Root powder: 3-6g daily. Decoction: 50-100ml twice daily.

balsam of peru.description: A resinous balsam used topically for wounds and skin conditions. Common allergen.
balsam of peru.activeConstituents: Benzyl benzoate, benzyl cinnamate, cinnamic acid, vanillin
balsam of peru.safetyClassification: Common contact allergen; external use only; patch test first
balsam of peru.dosageGuidelines: Topical: 5-20% in ointments. Not for internal use.

bamboo.description: Various bamboo species provide silica-rich material for bone and connective tissue health.
bamboo.usages: Bone health, hair/nail strength, fever, respiratory congestion
bamboo.activeConstituents: Silica (up to 70% in tabashir), flavonoids, phenolic acids
bamboo.safetyClassification: Generally safe; shoots contain cyanogenic glycosides - must be cooked
bamboo.dosageGuidelines: Bamboo silica (tabashir): 250-500mg daily. Shoots: cooked as food.

baobab.description: African superfruit extremely high in vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants.
baobab.usages: Immune support, digestive health, fever, diarrhea, skin health
baobab.activeConstituents: Vitamin C, fiber, polyphenols, calcium, potassium
baobab.dosageGuidelines: Fruit powder: 5-15g daily mixed in water or smoothies.

barberry.description: A berberine-containing shrub used for infections, liver support, and digestion.
barberry.usages: Infections, liver/gallbladder support, diarrhea, skin conditions
barberry.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may interact with CYP-metabolized medications
barberry.dosageGuidelines: Root bark: 2-4g as decoction. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

basil.description: A culinary and medicinal herb with adaptogenic and antimicrobial properties.
basil.usages: Stress, digestion, respiratory infections, inflammation, blood sugar
basil.activeConstituents: Eugenol, linalool, rosmarinic acid, ursolic acid
basil.safetyClassification: Generally safe; holy basil may have blood-thinning effects
basil.dosageGuidelines: Fresh herb: culinary. Tea: 2-4g dried. Holy basil: 300-600mg daily.

bay.description: Bay laurel leaves used in cooking and traditional medicine for digestion and pain.
bay.usages: Digestion, flatulence, joint pain, dandruff, insect repellent
bay.safetyClassification: Generally safe in culinary amounts; may cause contact dermatitis
bay.dosageGuidelines: Leaves: 1-2 in cooking. Tea: 1-2g dried leaves.

bayberry.description: An astringent bark used for diarrhea, sore throats, and circulatory stimulation.
bayberry.usages: Diarrhea, sore throat, bleeding gums, colds, poor circulation
bayberry.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; high doses may cause GI upset

bearberry.description: Uva ursi, a urinary antiseptic herb used for bladder and kidney infections.
bearberry.usages: Urinary tract infections, cystitis, kidney stones
bearberry.safetyClassification: Short-term use only (1-2 weeks); avoid in pregnancy, kidney disease
bearberry.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 3-12g daily divided. Extract: 400-800mg arbutin daily.

bee balm.description: Also called wild bergamot or Oswego tea. Used for digestive and respiratory complaints.
bee balm.usages: Colds, fever, digestive upset, sore throat, wound healing
bee balm.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy due to thymol content
bee balm.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

beeswax.description: Natural wax produced by bees, used as a base for salves, balms, and cosmetics.
beeswax.usages: Skin protection, wound healing base, lip balms, candles
beeswax.activeConstituents: Esters, fatty acids, hydrocarbons, propolis traces
beeswax.safetyClassification: Generally safe externally; rare bee product allergies possible
beeswax.dosageGuidelines: External use: as needed in formulations (typically 5-20% of salve).

belladonna.description: Deadly nightshade, highly toxic plant used in minute doses for spasms. POISONOUS.
belladonna.safetyClassification: HIGHLY TOXIC - prescription/professional use only; fatal in small doses
belladonna.dosageGuidelines: Standardized preparations only under medical supervision. NOT for home use.

benzoin.description: A fragrant resin used as an antiseptic, expectorant, and in incense/perfumery.
benzoin.usages: Respiratory infections, wound healing, skin protection, aromatherapy
benzoin.activeConstituents: Benzoic acid, cinnamic acid, vanillin, styrene
benzoin.safetyClassification: Generally safe externally; may cause sensitization; avoid ingestion
benzoin.dosageGuidelines: Tincture: topical as needed. Inhalation: few drops in steam.

betony.description: Wood betony, a nervine herb used for headaches, anxiety, and digestive complaints.
betony.usages: Headaches, anxiety, poor digestion, wound healing, neuralgia
betony.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; generally safe otherwise
betony.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

bhringraj.description: False daisy, an Ayurvedic herb famous for hair growth and liver support.
bhringraj.usages: Hair loss, liver disorders, skin conditions, premature graying
bhringraj.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may enhance effects of sedatives
bhringraj.dosageGuidelines: Juice: 10-20ml daily. Powder: 3-6g daily. Oil: topical for hair.

bibhitaki.description: Bahera, one of the three fruits in Triphala. Used for respiratory and digestive health.
bibhitaki.usages: Cough, sore throat, constipation, eye health, hair health
bibhitaki.activeConstituents: Tannins (gallic acid, ellagic acid), lignans, flavonoids
bibhitaki.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy; may cause loose stools initially
bibhitaki.dosageGuidelines: Fruit powder: 3-6g daily. Usually taken as part of Triphala.

bilberry.description: European blueberry, famous for eye health and vascular support.
bilberry.usages: Eye health, night vision, varicose veins, diarrhea, blood sugar
bilberry.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may enhance anticoagulant effects

bilva.description: Bael fruit, sacred in Hinduism and used in Ayurveda for digestive disorders.
bilva.usages: Diarrhea, dysentery, IBS, diabetes support, digestive weakness
bilva.safetyClassification: Generally safe; unripe fruit more astringent; avoid in constipation
bilva.dosageGuidelines: Ripe fruit pulp: 10-20g. Unripe powder: 3-6g for diarrhea.

birch.description: Birch bark and leaves used for urinary complaints, skin conditions, and pain.
birch.usages: UTIs, kidney stones, arthritis, skin conditions, gout
birch.activeConstituents: Betulin, betulinic acid, salicylates, flavonoids, tannins
birch.safetyClassification: Avoid with aspirin allergy; may increase urination
birch.dosageGuidelines: Leaf tea: 2-4g per cup, 3-4x daily. Bark decoction: 1-2g.

bitter kola.description: A West African nut used traditionally for respiratory infections and as a stimulant.
bitter kola.usages: Coughs, colds, bronchitis, infections, energy, libido
bitter kola.safetyClassification: Generally safe in moderate amounts; stimulant effects
bitter kola.dosageGuidelines: Nut: 1-2 nuts chewed daily. Not recommended in large quantities.

bitter melon.description: A tropical vegetable famous for blood sugar regulation in diabetes.
bitter melon.usages: Diabetes, digestive stimulation, parasites, skin conditions
bitter melon.safetyClassification: May cause hypoglycemia; avoid in pregnancy; G6PD caution

black cohosh.description: A Native American herb used primarily for menopausal symptoms and women's health.
black cohosh.usages: Menopause symptoms, menstrual cramps, arthritis, muscle pain
black cohosh.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, hormone-sensitive cancers; rare liver toxicity

black currant.description: A berry extremely high in vitamin C and anthocyanins for immune and eye health.
black currant.usages: Immune support, eye health, inflammation, sore throat, arthritis
black currant.activeConstituents: Anthocyanins, vitamin C, GLA (seed oil), proanthocyanidins
black currant.safetyClassification: Generally safe; seed oil may slow blood clotting
black currant.dosageGuidelines: Berries: as food. Seed oil: 500-1000mg daily. Juice: 100-200ml.

black haw.description: A uterine antispasmodic used for menstrual cramps and threatened miscarriage.
black haw.usages: Menstrual cramps, threatened miscarriage, afterpains, muscle spasms
black haw.safetyClassification: Use in pregnancy only under professional guidance

black pepper.description: The king of spices, enhances digestion and increases bioavailability of other herbs.
black pepper.usages: Digestion, nutrient absorption, respiratory congestion, metabolism
black pepper.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may increase absorption of medications
black pepper.dosageGuidelines: Culinary: as desired. Medicinal: 5-20mg piperine with other herbs.

black sesame.description: Nutrient-dense seeds used in TCM and Ayurveda for hair, bone, and kidney health.
black sesame.usages: Premature graying, constipation, bone health, kidney/liver tonic
black sesame.activeConstituents: Sesamin, sesamolin, lignans, calcium, iron, zinc

black walnut.description: The green hulls are used as an antiparasitic and antifungal remedy.
black walnut.usages: Intestinal parasites, fungal infections, skin conditions, diarrhea
black walnut.safetyClassification: Short-term use only; juglone may be toxic long-term; stains skin
black walnut.dosageGuidelines: Hull tincture: 10-20 drops 3x daily for 2 weeks max.

blackthorn.description: Sloe berries, extremely astringent until frost-touched, used for digestive complaints.
blackthorn.usages: Diarrhea, mouth inflammation, sore throat, spring tonic (flowers)
blackthorn.safetyClassification: Berries safe after frost; seeds contain amygdalin - avoid
blackthorn.dosageGuidelines: Berry syrup/wine: as prepared. Flower tea: 2-4g dried.

bloodroot.description: A potent Native American herb for respiratory conditions and skin growths. CAUSTIC.
bloodroot.usages: Respiratory congestion, warts, skin tags, dental plaque
bloodroot.safetyClassification: CAUSTIC - destroys tissue; internal use toxic; extreme caution
bloodroot.dosageGuidelines: Professional use only. NOT for home preparation.

blue cohosh.description: A Native American herb for labor induction and menstrual regulation. TOXIC in excess.
blue cohosh.safetyClassification: TOXIC - avoid in pregnancy until labor; cardiotoxic; professional only
blue cohosh.dosageGuidelines: Professional/midwife supervision only. NOT for self-administration.

bogbean.description: A bitter marsh plant used for digestive weakness and rheumatic complaints.
bogbean.usages: Poor appetite, indigestion, rheumatism, skin conditions
bogbean.safetyClassification: Avoid in diarrhea, colitis, pregnancy; may cause GI irritation
bogbean.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 1-3g as tea. Tincture: 1-3ml before meals.

boldo.description: A South American herb used for liver and gallbladder support.
boldo.safetyClassification: Avoid in bile duct obstruction, severe liver disease, pregnancy
boldo.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 1-2g as tea, 3x daily. Tincture: 0.5-1ml 3x daily.

boneset.description: A Native American herb used for fevers, flu, and bone pain.
boneset.safetyClassification: Short-term use only; contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids; avoid in pregnancy
boneset.dosageGuidelines: Hot tea: 2-4g dried herb. Tincture: 2-4ml every 2-3 hours acute.

borage.description: A cooling herb with cucumber-flavored leaves for adrenal support and skin health.
borage.usages: Adrenal exhaustion, skin conditions, PMS, lactation support
borage.safetyClassification: Seed oil safe; leaf contains PAs - avoid long-term; avoid in pregnancy
borage.dosageGuidelines: Seed oil: 1-3g daily. Fresh leaves: culinary, short-term.

brahmi.description: Can refer to Bacopa or Gotu kola - both are brain tonics in Ayurveda.
brahmi.usages: Memory, concentration, anxiety, epilepsy, wound healing
brahmi.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause GI upset; avoid in pregnancy

broom.description: Scotch broom, a cardiac herb for heart rhythm issues. TOXIC in excess.
broom.usages: Heart arrhythmias, edema, low blood pressure (historical)
broom.safetyClassification: TOXIC - professional use only; avoid in pregnancy, heart block

buchu.description: A South African herb used for urinary tract infections and kidney health.
buchu.usages: UTIs, cystitis, prostatitis, kidney stones, digestive complaints
buchu.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, kidney infections; pulegone hepatotoxic in high doses
buchu.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 1-2g as tea, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

buckthorn.description: A strong laxative bark that must be aged before use to reduce griping.
buckthorn.safetyClassification: Must be aged 1+ year; avoid in pregnancy, IBD, children; short-term
buckthorn.dosageGuidelines: Aged bark: 0.5-2.5g at bedtime. Not for long-term use.

bulbine.description: A South African succulent with gel similar to aloe for burns and wounds.
bulbine.usages: Burns, wounds, skin conditions, insect bites, cold sores
bulbine.safetyClassification: Generally safe topically; limited internal use data
bulbine.dosageGuidelines: Gel: apply fresh to affected area as needed.

burdock.description: A blood-purifying root used for skin conditions and gentle detoxification.
burdock.usages: Acne, eczema, psoriasis, blood purification, liver support
burdock.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause allergy in Asteraceae-sensitive individuals

cacao.description: The source of chocolate, used medicinally as a stimulant and mood enhancer.
cacao.usages: Mood support, cardiovascular health, energy, antioxidant
cacao.safetyClassification: Generally safe; stimulant effects; toxic to dogs; may trigger migraines
cacao.dosageGuidelines: Raw cacao: 1-2 tbsp daily. Dark chocolate: 20-40g daily.

calamus.description: Sweet flag, an aromatic rhizome for digestion and cognitive function. Contains β-asarone.
calamus.ml: Carminative, nervine, cognitive enhancer, bitter tonic
calamus.usages: Indigestion, memory, speech disorders, anxiety, smoking cessation
calamus.safetyClassification: β-asarone is carcinogenic - use only asarone-free varieties; avoid in pregnancy

calendula.description: Pot marigold, a gentle wound-healing flower safe for sensitive skin and internal use.
calendula.usages: Wounds, burns, eczema, conjunctivitis, gastric ulcers, lymphatic support
calendula.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if allergic to Asteraceae family
calendula.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g flowers per cup. Tincture: 1-4ml 3x daily. Topical: as needed.

california poppy.description: A gentle sedative herb native to California, safe for children and adults.
california poppy.usages: Insomnia, anxiety, nervous tension, pain, bedwetting in children
california poppy.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy; may enhance sedatives
california poppy.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb. Tincture: 2-4ml before bed. Children: half dose.

camphor.description: A waxy substance from camphor trees used topically for pain and congestion.
camphor.usages: Muscle pain, arthritis, respiratory congestion, skin irritation
camphor.safetyClassification: EXTERNAL USE ONLY; toxic if ingested; avoid in children under 2

caraway.description: A digestive seed used for gas, bloating, and colic in infants.
caraway.usages: Flatulence, bloating, colic, appetite stimulation, milk production
caraway.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid essential oil in pregnancy
caraway.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-5g crushed in tea. Essential oil: 1-2 drops diluted.

cardamom.description: The queen of spices, used for digestion, breath freshening, and respiratory health.
cardamom.usages: Indigestion, nausea, bad breath, respiratory congestion, libido
cardamom.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-2g crushed. Pods: 2-3 chewed or in tea.

cascara.description: Sacred bark, a strong laxative that must be aged before use.
cascara.safetyClassification: Must be aged 1+ year; avoid in pregnancy, IBD; short-term use only
cascara.dosageGuidelines: Aged bark: 0.5-1.5g at bedtime. Not for long-term use.

castor oil.description: A thick oil from castor beans used as a laxative and topically for skin/hair.
castor oil.usages: Constipation, skin conditions, hair growth, labor induction (traditional)
castor oil.activeConstituents: Ricinoleic acid (85-90%), oleic acid, linoleic acid
castor oil.safetyClassification: Internal: strong laxative, avoid in pregnancy; External: generally safe
castor oil.dosageGuidelines: Laxative: 15-60ml single dose. Topical: as needed (castor oil packs).

cat's claw.description: A South American vine used for immune support and inflammation.
cat's claw.usages: Immune support, arthritis, viral infections, digestive complaints
cat's claw.activeConstituents: Pentacyclic oxindole alkaloids, quinovic acid glycosides, tannins
cat's claw.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, autoimmune conditions, before surgery
cat's claw.dosageGuidelines: Bark: 1-3g as decoction. Standardized extract: 250-350mg daily.

cayenne.description: Hot chili pepper used to stimulate circulation and relieve pain.
cayenne.usages: Poor circulation, pain relief, digestion, heart health, metabolism
cayenne.activeConstituents: Capsaicin, dihydrocapsaicin, vitamins A and C
cayenne.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may irritate GI tract; avoid on broken skin
cayenne.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 30-120mg in capsules. Topical: 0.025-0.075% capsaicin cream.

celandine.description: Greater celandine, used for liver/gallbladder support and wart removal. TOXIC in excess.
celandine.usages: Gallbladder disorders, warts (topical sap), liver support
celandine.safetyClassification: TOXIC in high doses; hepatotoxic; professional use only; avoid in pregnancy
celandine.dosageGuidelines: Professional supervision required. Topical sap for warts only.

chaga.description: A medicinal mushroom growing on birch trees, used for immune and antioxidant support.
chaga.usages: Immune support, antioxidant, blood sugar, inflammation, cancer support
chaga.activeConstituents: Beta-glucans, betulinic acid, melanin, polyphenols, triterpenes
chaga.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with anticoagulants and diabetes medications

chamomile.description: A gentle, apple-scented flower used for relaxation, digestion, and skin conditions.
chamomile.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, digestive upset, skin irritation, teething
chamomile.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if allergic to Asteraceae; may enhance sedatives
chamomile.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g flowers per cup, 3-4x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

chanca piedra.description: Stone breaker, a tropical herb used for kidney stones and liver support.
chanca piedra.usages: Kidney stones, gallstones, liver protection, urinary infections, diabetes
chanca piedra.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar; avoid in pregnancy
chanca piedra.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 4-5g dried herb daily. Capsules: 500-1000mg 2-3x daily.

chaparral.description: Creosote bush, a potent antioxidant herb. Controversial due to liver toxicity reports.
chaparral.usages: Infections, skin conditions, arthritis, cancer support (traditional)
chaparral.safetyClassification: HEPATOTOXIC - liver damage reported; avoid internal use; external only
chaparral.dosageGuidelines: External use only. Internal use not recommended.

chaste tree.description: Vitex, a hormone-balancing herb primarily used for women's reproductive health.
chaste tree.usages: PMS, menstrual irregularities, menopause, acne, infertility support
chaste tree.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, hormone-sensitive conditions; may interact with dopamine drugs

chia.description: Nutrient-dense seeds high in omega-3s, fiber, and protein.
chia.usages: Nutrition, constipation, blood sugar regulation, hydration
chia.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause choking if not hydrated; blood thinner caution

chicory.description: A bitter root used as a coffee substitute and for liver/digestive support.
chicory.ml: Bitter tonic, cholagogue, prebiotic, mild laxative
chicory.usages: Liver support, digestion, constipation, coffee substitute, gut health
chicory.activeConstituents: Inulin, sesquiterpene lactones, chicoric acid, flavonoids
chicory.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if allergic to Asteraceae; may cause gas initially
chicory.dosageGuidelines: Roasted root: as coffee substitute. Raw root: 3-5g daily.

chirata.description: An extremely bitter herb used in Ayurveda for fever and liver disorders.
chirata.usages: Fever, malaria, liver disorders, diabetes, skin diseases
chirata.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause GI upset; use short-term

cinnamon.description: A warming spice used for blood sugar regulation, digestion, and circulation.
cinnamon.usages: Blood sugar, digestion, colds, circulation, menstrual cramps
cinnamon.safetyClassification: Ceylon (verum) preferred; cassia high in coumarin - limit intake; avoid large doses in pregnancy
cinnamon.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 1-6g daily. Ceylon preferred for long-term use.

clove.description: A pungent spice famous for dental pain relief and antimicrobial properties.
clove.usages: Toothache, digestive complaints, infections, nausea, bad breath
clove.safetyClassification: Generally safe in culinary amounts; eugenol can irritate mucous membranes
clove.dosageGuidelines: Whole cloves: 1-3 chewed. Essential oil: 1-2 drops diluted for dental use.

coca.description: The source plant of cocaine, traditionally used in Andes for altitude sickness and energy.
coca.usages: Altitude sickness, fatigue, appetite suppression, local anesthesia (traditional)
coca.safetyClassification: CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE in most countries; traditional leaf use legal in some Andean regions
coca.dosageGuidelines: Traditional: leaf chewing or tea in legal regions only.

codonopsis.description: Dang Shen, a gentle qi tonic used as a ginseng substitute in TCM.
codonopsis.usages: Fatigue, poor appetite, weak digestion, immune support, lung health
codonopsis.dosageGuidelines: Sliced root: 9-30g in decoction. Often combined with other herbs.

coltsfoot.description: A traditional cough remedy. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids - use with caution.
coltsfoot.safetyClassification: Contains hepatotoxic PAs - avoid long-term use; avoid in pregnancy; use PA-free extracts
coltsfoot.dosageGuidelines: PA-free preparations only. Tea: 1-2g short-term. Not for prolonged use.

comfrey.description: A powerful wound healer for external use. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids.
comfrey.activeConstituents: Allantoin, rosmarinic acid, pyrrolizidine alkaloids, mucilage
comfrey.safetyClassification: EXTERNAL USE ONLY - PAs are hepatotoxic; avoid on broken skin; avoid in pregnancy
comfrey.dosageGuidelines: External only: poultices, salves. Never ingest.

cordyceps.description: A medicinal fungus used for energy, athletic performance, and lung health.
cordyceps.usages: Fatigue, athletic performance, respiratory health, libido, kidney support
cordyceps.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with immunosuppressants

coriander.description: Cilantro seeds, used for digestion and as a gentle detoxifier.
coriander.usages: Digestion, heavy metal detox, inflammation, blood sugar
coriander.safetyClassification: Generally safe; some people have genetic aversion to cilantro leaves
coriander.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-3g crushed in tea. Fresh leaves: culinary amounts.

cowslip.description: A European primrose used for respiratory complaints and as a mild sedative.
cowslip.activeConstituents: Saponins, flavonoids, phenolic glycosides, essential oil
cowslip.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy; may cause allergic reactions

cranberry.description: A tart berry famous for preventing urinary tract infections.
cranberry.usages: UTI prevention, antioxidant support, oral health
cranberry.activeConstituents: Proanthocyanidins (PACs), anthocyanins, organic acids, vitamin C
cranberry.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with warfarin; high oxalate content

cumin.description: A warming digestive spice used in cuisines worldwide.

damiana.description: A Mexican herb traditionally used as an aphrodisiac and mood enhancer.
damiana.usages: Low libido, depression, anxiety, urinary complaints
damiana.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy; may affect blood sugar

dandelion.description: A common weed with powerful liver, digestive, and diuretic properties.
dandelion.usages: Liver support, digestion, water retention, skin conditions, detoxification
dandelion.activeConstituents: Taraxacin, inulin, sesquiterpene lactones, potassium, vitamins
dandelion.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if allergic to Asteraceae; may interact with diuretics
dandelion.dosageGuidelines: Root: 2-8g as decoction. Leaf: 4-10g as tea. Tincture: 2-5ml 3x daily.

devil's claw.description: An African herb used for arthritis, back pain, and digestive complaints.
devil's claw.usages: Arthritis, back pain, tendinitis, digestive weakness, headaches
devil's claw.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, peptic ulcers, gallstones; may interact with anticoagulants
devil's claw.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 600-1200mg harpagoside daily. Tea: 4-5g root.

dong quai.description: Female ginseng, a blood-building herb used in TCM for women's health.
dong quai.usages: Menstrual irregularities, anemia, menopausal symptoms, pain
dong quai.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, heavy bleeding, before surgery; photosensitizing
dong quai.dosageGuidelines: Sliced root: 3-15g in decoction. Usually in formulas.

echinacea.description: Purple coneflower, a popular immune-stimulating herb for colds and infections.
echinacea.usages: Colds, flu, infections, wound healing, immune support
echinacea.activeConstituents: Alkamides, polysaccharides, caffeic acid derivatives, echinacosides
echinacea.safetyClassification: Generally safe short-term; avoid in autoimmune conditions; Asteraceae allergy caution
echinacea.dosageGuidelines: Tincture: 2-5ml 3x daily at onset. Tea: 2-3g. Use for 10-14 days max.

elderberry.description: Dark berries used for flu, colds, and immune support. Flowers are also medicinal.
elderberry.usages: Flu, colds, fever, sinus infections, immune support
elderberry.activeConstituents: Anthocyanins, flavonoids, sambucine, vitamins A and C
elderberry.safetyClassification: Cooked berries safe; raw berries/bark/leaves toxic; avoid in autoimmune conditions
elderberry.dosageGuidelines: Syrup: 15ml 4x daily during illness. Extract: 175mg 2x daily.

elecampane.description: A lung tonic herb used for chronic respiratory conditions and digestive weakness.
elecampane.usages: Chronic coughs, bronchitis, asthma, digestive weakness, parasites
elecampane.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause allergic reactions; large doses may cause GI upset

eleuthero.description: Siberian ginseng, an adaptogen for stress, stamina, and immune support.
eleuthero.usages: Stress, fatigue, athletic performance, immune support, concentration
eleuthero.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in hypertension; may interact with sedatives, digoxin

epazote.description: A Mexican herb used for digestive complaints and as an antiparasitic.
epazote.usages: Gas, bloating, intestinal parasites, menstrual regulation
epazote.safetyClassification: Culinary amounts safe; essential oil toxic; avoid in pregnancy
epazote.dosageGuidelines: Fresh leaves: culinary amounts in beans. Tea: 1-2g short-term.

ephedra.description: Ma Huang, a powerful bronchodilator and stimulant. Banned in many countries.
ephedra.usages: Asthma, bronchitis, nasal congestion, weight loss (historical)
ephedra.safetyClassification: BANNED/RESTRICTED in many countries; cardiovascular risks; avoid with heart conditions
ephedra.dosageGuidelines: Professional use only where legal. Traditional TCM: 3-9g in formulas.

eucalyptus.description: An aromatic tree used for respiratory infections and muscle pain.
eucalyptus.usages: Coughs, colds, sinusitis, muscle pain, wound healing
eucalyptus.safetyClassification: Generally safe in diluted form; essential oil toxic if ingested; avoid in children under 2
eucalyptus.dosageGuidelines: Inhalation: few drops in steam. Topical: 2-5% diluted. Tea: 2-3g leaves.

euphorbia.description: A large genus with various medicinal species. Latex is often caustic.
euphorbia.ml: Varies by species - expectorant, purgative, rubefacient
euphorbia.safetyClassification: Many species TOXIC; latex caustic; professional guidance required
euphorbia.dosageGuidelines: Species-specific. E. hirta: 1-2g dried herb. Latex: topical only with caution.

evening primrose.description: A source of gamma-linolenic acid (GLA) used for skin and hormonal health.
evening primrose.usages: Eczema, PMS, breast pain, diabetic neuropathy, rheumatoid arthritis
evening primrose.activeConstituents: Gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), linoleic acid, vitamin E
evening primrose.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may increase bleeding risk; avoid before surgery

fennel.description: A licorice-flavored seed used for digestion, colic, and milk production.
fennel.usages: Gas, bloating, colic, lactation support, respiratory congestion
fennel.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid large doses in pregnancy (estrogenic)
fennel.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-5g crushed in tea. Essential oil: 1-2 drops diluted.

fenugreek.description: A seed used for blood sugar, digestion, and increasing milk supply.
fenugreek.usages: Diabetes, lactation, digestive complaints, respiratory congestion
fenugreek.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may lower blood sugar; maple syrup odor in sweat/urine

feverfew.description: A traditional remedy for migraines and fever.
feverfew.usages: Migraine prevention, fever, arthritis, menstrual pain
feverfew.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause mouth ulcers; avoid if allergic to Asteraceae
feverfew.dosageGuidelines: Fresh leaves: 2-3 daily. Dried: 50-125mg daily. Standardized: 0.2-0.4% parthenolide.

flaxseed.description: A seed rich in omega-3s and lignans, used for constipation and heart health.
flaxseed.usages: Constipation, heart health, menopausal symptoms, skin health
flaxseed.safetyClassification: Generally safe; take with plenty of water; may affect hormone-sensitive conditions
flaxseed.dosageGuidelines: Ground seeds: 1-4 tbsp daily with water. Oil: 1-2 tbsp daily.

fo-ti.description: He Shou Wu, a Chinese longevity herb for hair, vitality, and liver health.
fo-ti.usages: Premature graying, vitality, liver support, constipation (raw)
fo-ti.safetyClassification: Hepatotoxicity reported; use prepared (cured) form; avoid in liver disease
fo-ti.dosageGuidelines: Prepared root: 6-15g in decoction. Raw form: laxative only, short-term.

frankincense.description: A sacred resin used for inflammation, respiratory health, and meditation.
frankincense.usages: Arthritis, asthma, IBD, wound healing, meditation
frankincense.activeConstituents: Boswellic acids, incensole, terpenes, essential oil
frankincense.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with NSAIDs; avoid in pregnancy

garlic.description: A pungent bulb with powerful antimicrobial and cardiovascular benefits.
garlic.usages: Infections, heart health, high cholesterol, immune support
garlic.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may increase bleeding risk; avoid before surgery
garlic.dosageGuidelines: Fresh: 2-4 cloves daily. Aged extract: 600-1200mg daily.

gentian.description: One of the most bitter herbs, used for digestive weakness and appetite.
gentian.usages: Poor appetite, indigestion, bloating, liver/gallbladder support
gentian.safetyClassification: Avoid in peptic ulcers, GERD, pregnancy; may cause headaches
gentian.dosageGuidelines: Root: 0.5-1g before meals. Tincture: 1-2ml before meals.

ginger.description: A warming rhizome used for nausea, digestion, and circulation.
ginger.usages: Nausea, motion sickness, digestion, colds, inflammation, pain
ginger.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may increase bleeding risk in high doses
ginger.dosageGuidelines: Fresh: 2-4g daily. Dried: 0.5-2g daily. Tea: 1-2g per cup.

ginkgo.description: A living fossil tree used for memory, circulation, and eye health.
ginkgo.usages: Memory, dementia, tinnitus, peripheral circulation, macular degeneration
ginkgo.safetyClassification: May increase bleeding; avoid before surgery; avoid with anticoagulants

ginseng.description: Asian/Korean ginseng, a premier adaptogen for energy and vitality.
ginseng.usages: Fatigue, stress, cognitive function, immune support, libido
ginseng.safetyClassification: Avoid in hypertension, insomnia; may interact with stimulants, MAOIs

goji.description: Wolfberry, a nutrient-dense berry used in TCM for longevity and eye health.
goji.usages: Eye health, immune support, longevity, liver/kidney tonic
goji.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with warfarin and diabetes medications

goldenseal.description: A berberine-rich herb used for infections and mucous membrane health.
goldenseal.usages: Infections, digestive complaints, eye/ear infections, sinus issues
goldenseal.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; endangered species - use sustainably; short-term use
goldenseal.dosageGuidelines: Root: 0.5-1g 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Use 2-3 weeks max.

gotu kola.description: A brain tonic and wound healer used in Ayurveda and TCM.
gotu kola.usages: Memory, anxiety, wound healing, varicose veins, skin health
gotu kola.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause GI upset; avoid in pregnancy
gotu kola.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-2g 3x daily. Standardized extract: 60-120mg triterpenes daily.

green tea.description: A minimally oxidized tea with powerful antioxidant and metabolic benefits.
green tea.usages: Antioxidant support, weight management, cognitive function, heart health
green tea.safetyClassification: Generally safe; contains caffeine; high doses may affect liver
green tea.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 3-5 cups daily. Extract: 250-500mg EGCG daily.

guarana.description: A Brazilian seed with high caffeine content, used for energy and weight loss.
guarana.usages: Fatigue, weight loss, cognitive enhancement, athletic performance
guarana.safetyClassification: High caffeine - avoid in anxiety, insomnia, heart conditions, pregnancy

guduchi.description: Giloy, an Ayurvedic immunomodulator and rejuvenative herb.
guduchi.usages: Immune support, fever, liver protection, diabetes, allergies
guduchi.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar; avoid in autoimmune conditions

guggul.description: An Ayurvedic resin used for cholesterol, arthritis, and thyroid support.
guggul.activeConstituents: Guggulsterones (E and Z), guggulipid, essential oil
guggul.safetyClassification: May interact with thyroid medications, statins, blood thinners; avoid in pregnancy

haritaki.description: The king of medicines in Ayurveda, one of three fruits in Triphala.
haritaki.usages: Constipation, digestion, detoxification, longevity, eye health
haritaki.activeConstituents: Chebulic acid, chebulagic acid, tannins, gallic acid
haritaki.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in pregnancy, dehydration, severe debility
haritaki.dosageGuidelines: Fruit powder: 3-6g daily. Usually taken as part of Triphala.

hawthorn.description: A heart tonic berry and flower used for cardiovascular support.
hawthorn.usages: Heart failure, hypertension, angina, anxiety, arrhythmias
hawthorn.safetyClassification: May interact with cardiac medications; use under supervision for heart conditions
hawthorn.dosageGuidelines: Berries/flowers: 3-5g as tea. Standardized extract: 160-900mg daily.

henna.description: A plant dye used for hair coloring and traditional body art.
henna.usages: Hair dye, body art, skin conditions, fever (traditional)
henna.safetyClassification: External use generally safe; may cause allergic reactions; avoid 'black henna'
henna.dosageGuidelines: External: paste applied to hair/skin. Not for internal use.

hibiscus.description: A tart flower used for blood pressure, cholesterol, and as a cooling drink.
hibiscus.usages: High blood pressure, high cholesterol, fever, UTIs, weight management
hibiscus.activeConstituents: Anthocyanins, organic acids, polysaccharides, vitamin C
hibiscus.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood pressure; avoid in pregnancy (emmenagogue)
hibiscus.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1.5-3g dried calyces per cup, 2-3x daily.

holy basil.description: Tulsi, a sacred adaptogenic herb in Ayurveda for stress and immunity.
holy basil.usages: Stress, anxiety, respiratory infections, blood sugar, inflammation
holy basil.activeConstituents: Eugenol, rosmarinic acid, ursolic acid, ocimumosides
holy basil.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may have blood-thinning effects; avoid before surgery

honeysuckle.description: Jin Yin Hua, a cooling herb used in TCM for infections and fever.
honeysuckle.usages: Colds, flu, fever, sore throat, skin infections, UTIs
honeysuckle.safetyClassification: Generally safe; berries of some species toxic
honeysuckle.dosageGuidelines: Flowers: 6-15g in decoction. Often combined with forsythia.

hops.description: A sedative flower used for insomnia, anxiety, and digestive complaints.
hops.usages: Insomnia, anxiety, restlessness, digestive weakness, menopause
hops.safetyClassification: Avoid in depression; estrogenic - avoid in hormone-sensitive conditions
hops.dosageGuidelines: Dried strobiles: 0.5-1g as tea. Tincture: 1-2ml before bed.

horehound.description: A bitter herb used for coughs, bronchitis, and digestive complaints.
horehound.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, asthma, poor appetite, bloating
horehound.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause diarrhea in large doses
horehound.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-2g as tea 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

horseradish.description: A pungent root used for sinus congestion and urinary infections.
horseradish.usages: Sinus congestion, UTIs, bronchitis, poor circulation
horseradish.activeConstituents: Glucosinolates, sinigrin, allyl isothiocyanate, vitamin C
horseradish.safetyClassification: May irritate GI tract; avoid in peptic ulcers, kidney disease, hypothyroidism
horseradish.dosageGuidelines: Fresh root: 2-4g grated. Prepared: 1 tsp with meals.

horsetail.description: A silica-rich herb used for bone, hair, nail, and urinary health.
horsetail.usages: Bone health, hair/nail strength, UTIs, wound healing, edema
horsetail.safetyClassification: Avoid long-term use; contains thiaminase; avoid in kidney disease, pregnancy
horsetail.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-3g dried herb. Extract: 300mg 3x daily. Use intermittently.

hyssop.description: A biblical herb used for respiratory infections and digestive complaints.
hyssop.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, colds, digestive upset, sore throat
hyssop.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, epilepsy; essential oil neurotoxic in high doses
hyssop.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

iceland moss.description: A lichen used for respiratory and digestive complaints, rich in mucilage.
iceland moss.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, sore throat, gastritis, loss of appetite
iceland moss.activeConstituents: Lichenin, isolichenin, usnic acid, fumarprotocetraric acid
iceland moss.safetyClassification: Generally safe; bitter compounds may cause GI upset
iceland moss.dosageGuidelines: Dried lichen: 4-6g as decoction. Lozenges: as directed.

juniper.description: An aromatic berry used for urinary infections and digestive complaints.
juniper.usages: UTIs, water retention, digestive complaints, arthritis, gout
juniper.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, kidney disease; short-term use only (4-6 weeks max)
juniper.dosageGuidelines: Berries: 1-2g crushed in tea. Tincture: 1-2ml 3x daily.

kava.description: A Pacific Island root used for anxiety and relaxation. Liver concerns noted.
kava.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, stress, muscle tension, social anxiety
kava.safetyClassification: Hepatotoxicity reported; avoid with alcohol, liver disease; banned in some countries
kava.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 100-250mg kavalactones daily. Traditional: water extraction.

kudzu.description: A vine used in TCM for alcohol cravings, hangovers, and cardiovascular health.
kudzu.usages: Alcohol cravings, hangovers, menopausal symptoms, cardiovascular health
kudzu.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with diabetes medications, hormone therapies
kudzu.dosageGuidelines: Root: 9-15g in decoction. Standardized extract: 100-500mg daily.

lavender.description: A fragrant flower used for relaxation, sleep, and skin conditions.
lavender.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, headaches, burns, skin irritation, digestive upset
lavender.safetyClassification: Generally safe; essential oil may cause skin sensitization; avoid in pregnancy (large doses)
lavender.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g flowers. Essential oil: 1-4 drops diluted. Capsules: 80-160mg.

lemon balm.description: A calming mint-family herb used for anxiety, sleep, and digestive complaints.
lemon balm.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, cold sores, digestive upset, thyroid support
lemon balm.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may affect thyroid function; avoid with hypothyroidism
lemon balm.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Extract: 300-600mg daily.

licorice.description: A sweet root used for adrenal support, digestion, and respiratory health.
licorice.usages: Adrenal fatigue, coughs, gastritis, ulcers, sore throat
licorice.safetyClassification: Avoid in hypertension, heart disease, pregnancy; may cause potassium loss

linden.description: A gentle flower used for anxiety, colds, and cardiovascular support.
linden.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, colds, fever, high blood pressure, palpitations
linden.safetyClassification: Generally safe; rare cardiac toxicity with excessive long-term use
linden.dosageGuidelines: Flowers: 2-4g as tea 2-3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

lobelia.description: A powerful respiratory herb and smoking cessation aid. TOXIC in excess.
lobelia.usages: Asthma, bronchitis, smoking cessation, muscle spasms
lobelia.safetyClassification: TOXIC in high doses; professional use only; avoid in pregnancy, heart disease
lobelia.dosageGuidelines: Professional supervision required. Tincture: 0.5-1ml in acute situations.

lungwort.description: A spotted leaf herb used for respiratory conditions based on Doctrine of Signatures.
lungwort.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, sore throat, respiratory infections
lungwort.activeConstituents: Mucilage, tannins, saponins, silicic acid, allantoin
lungwort.safetyClassification: Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids - use PA-free preparations; avoid in pregnancy
lungwort.dosageGuidelines: PA-free preparations only. Tea: 1-2g dried herb 3x daily.

maca.description: A Peruvian root vegetable used for energy, libido, and hormonal balance.
maca.usages: Energy, libido, fertility, menopause, athletic performance
maca.activeConstituents: Macamides, macaenes, glucosinolates, amino acids, minerals
maca.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may affect hormone-sensitive conditions; avoid with thyroid issues
maca.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 1.5-3g daily. Gelatinized form may be easier to digest.

magnolia.description: A TCM herb (Hou Po) used for anxiety, digestive complaints, and respiratory issues.
magnolia.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may enhance sedatives; use under guidance
magnolia.dosageGuidelines: Bark: 3-10g in decoction. Standardized extract: 200-400mg daily.

maitake.description: A medicinal mushroom used for immune support and blood sugar regulation.
maitake.usages: Immune support, diabetes, cancer support, weight management
maitake.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar; may interact with immunosuppressants

manjistha.description: Indian madder, an Ayurvedic blood purifier and lymphatic herb.
manjistha.usages: Skin conditions, blood purification, lymphatic congestion, menstrual disorders
manjistha.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may color urine/stool red (harmless)
manjistha.dosageGuidelines: Root powder: 3-6g daily. Decoction: 50-100ml twice daily.

marshmallow.description: A soothing mucilaginous herb for digestive and respiratory irritation.
marshmallow.usages: Sore throat, coughs, gastritis, ulcers, skin irritation
marshmallow.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may slow absorption of other medications
marshmallow.dosageGuidelines: Root: 2-5g as cold infusion. Leaf: 2-5g as tea. Take separately from medications.

meadowsweet.description: A natural source of salicylates, used for pain, fever, and digestive complaints.
meadowsweet.usages: Pain, fever, heartburn, gastritis, diarrhea, arthritis
meadowsweet.safetyClassification: Avoid with aspirin allergy; avoid in children with viral infections (Reye's risk)
meadowsweet.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-6g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

milk thistle.description: The premier liver-protective herb, used for liver disease and detoxification.
milk thistle.usages: Liver disease, hepatitis, cirrhosis, detoxification, mushroom poisoning
milk thistle.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar; mild laxative effect
milk thistle.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 140-420mg silymarin daily in divided doses.

moringa.description: A highly nutritious tree used for malnutrition, inflammation, and blood sugar.
moringa.usages: Malnutrition, diabetes, inflammation, lactation support, anemia
moringa.activeConstituents: Isothiocyanates, quercetin, chlorogenic acid, vitamins, minerals
moringa.safetyClassification: Leaves safe; avoid root/bark in pregnancy (uterine stimulant)
moringa.dosageGuidelines: Leaf powder: 2-6g daily. Fresh leaves: as food.

motherwort.description: A heart and uterine tonic used for palpitations, anxiety, and menstrual issues.
motherwort.usages: Palpitations, anxiety, menstrual pain, menopausal symptoms, hyperthyroidism
motherwort.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy (uterine stimulant); may interact with cardiac/thyroid medications
motherwort.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

mucuna.description: Velvet bean, a natural source of L-DOPA used for mood and Parkinson's support.
mucuna.usages: Parkinson's support, mood, libido, fertility, stress
mucuna.safetyClassification: May interact with Parkinson's medications, MAOIs; avoid in psychosis
mucuna.dosageGuidelines: Seed powder: 2.5-5g daily. Standardized extract: 100-500mg L-DOPA daily.

mugwort.description: A bitter herb used for digestion, menstruation, and vivid dreams.
mugwort.usages: Digestive weakness, menstrual regulation, vivid dreams, moxibustion
mugwort.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy (emmenagogue); contains thujone - avoid long-term use
mugwort.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-2g as tea. Tincture: 1-2ml before meals.

mullein.description: A soothing respiratory herb used for coughs and ear infections.
mullein.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, asthma, ear infections (oil), sore throat
mullein.safetyClassification: Generally safe; strain tea well to remove irritating hairs
mullein.dosageGuidelines: Leaf tea: 2-4g. Flower oil: 2-3 drops in ear. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

myrrh.description: A sacred resin used for infections, wound healing, and oral health.
myrrh.usages: Mouth ulcers, gum disease, wounds, respiratory infections, skin conditions
myrrh.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may lower blood sugar; avoid with bleeding disorders
myrrh.dosageGuidelines: Tincture: 1-2ml 3x daily. Mouthwash: diluted tincture. Topical: as needed.

neem.description: A bitter Ayurvedic herb used for skin conditions, infections, and blood sugar.
neem.usages: Skin conditions, infections, diabetes, parasites, dental health
neem.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, children; may lower blood sugar; oil toxic internally
neem.dosageGuidelines: Leaf powder: 1-2g daily. External: oil/paste as needed. Not for long-term internal use.

nettle.description: A nutritive herb used for allergies, prostate health, and as a spring tonic.
nettle.usages: Allergies, BPH, arthritis, anemia, kidney support, hair health
nettle.activeConstituents: Chlorophyll, minerals (iron, silica), flavonoids, lectins, lignans (root)
nettle.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with blood thinners, diabetes medications
nettle.dosageGuidelines: Leaf tea: 2-4g 3x daily. Root: 300-600mg daily for prostate.

nigella.description: Black seed, used in Islamic medicine for 'everything except death'.
nigella.usages: Immune support, allergies, diabetes, digestive complaints, skin conditions
nigella.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar and blood pressure
nigella.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 1-2g daily. Oil: 1-3 tsp daily. Capsules: 500-1000mg 2x daily.

nutmeg.description: A warming spice used for digestion and sleep. TOXIC in high doses.
nutmeg.usages: Indigestion, insomnia, pain, diarrhea, bad breath
nutmeg.safetyClassification: TOXIC in high doses (>5g); hallucinogenic; avoid in pregnancy
nutmeg.dosageGuidelines: Culinary: pinch to 1/4 tsp. Medicinal: max 1g daily.

oat straw.description: A nervine tonic used for nervous exhaustion, stress, and skin health.
oat straw.usages: Nervous exhaustion, anxiety, insomnia, skin conditions, convalescence
oat straw.activeConstituents: Avenanthramides, saponins, flavonoids, silica, B vitamins
oat straw.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if gluten-sensitive (may be contaminated)
oat straw.dosageGuidelines: Dried straw: 3-5g as tea. Tincture: 3-5ml 3x daily. Milky oat tops preferred.

olive leaf.description: An antimicrobial herb used for infections and cardiovascular health.
olive leaf.usages: Infections, high blood pressure, diabetes, immune support
olive leaf.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood pressure and blood sugar
olive leaf.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 5-10g as tea. Extract: 500-1000mg oleuropein daily.

onion.description: A common vegetable with antimicrobial and cardiovascular benefits.
onion.usages: Colds, coughs, infections, blood sugar, heart health
onion.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause GI upset; toxic to pets
onion.dosageGuidelines: Fresh: 50-100g daily. Juice: 2-3 tbsp. Syrup: as prepared.

oregon grape.description: A berberine-containing root used for skin conditions and infections.
oregon grape.usages: Psoriasis, eczema, infections, digestive complaints, liver support
oregon grape.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may interact with CYP-metabolized medications
oregon grape.dosageGuidelines: Root bark: 1-3g as decoction. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

osha.description: A Native American respiratory herb from the Rocky Mountains.
osha.usages: Colds, flu, coughs, sore throat, altitude sickness
osha.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; endangered - use sustainably; may cause photosensitivity
osha.dosageGuidelines: Root: 1-3g as decoction. Tincture: 1-2ml 3-4x daily during acute illness.

papaya.description: A tropical fruit with digestive enzymes and antiparasitic properties.
papaya.usages: Digestion, parasites, inflammation, wound healing, constipation
papaya.activeConstituents: Papain, chymopapain, carpaine, vitamins A and C
papaya.safetyClassification: Fruit safe; seeds/latex avoid in pregnancy; papain may cause allergies
papaya.dosageGuidelines: Fruit: as food. Seeds: 1 tsp for parasites. Enzyme: 500-1000mg with meals.

parsley.description: A culinary herb with diuretic and nutritive properties.
parsley.usages: Water retention, UTIs, bad breath, digestion, menstrual support
parsley.activeConstituents: Apiol, myristicin, flavonoids, vitamins C and K, iron
parsley.safetyClassification: Culinary amounts safe; avoid large medicinal doses in pregnancy
parsley.dosageGuidelines: Fresh: as food. Tea: 2-4g dried. Avoid essential oil internally.

passionflower.description: A gentle sedative herb used for anxiety, insomnia, and nervous tension.
passionflower.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, nervous tension, ADHD, withdrawal support
passionflower.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may enhance sedatives; avoid in pregnancy
passionflower.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-2g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Extract: 250-500mg daily.

pau d'arco.description: A South American bark used for infections and immune support.
pau d'arco.usages: Candida, infections, cancer support, immune deficiency
pau d'arco.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may interact with anticoagulants; high doses toxic
pau d'arco.dosageGuidelines: Bark decoction: 2-4g simmered 15-20 min. Capsules: 500-1000mg 2-3x daily.

pelargonium.description: South African geranium used for respiratory infections and bronchitis.
pelargonium.usages: Bronchitis, colds, sinusitis, sore throat, tonsillitis
pelargonium.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with anticoagulants; rare liver concerns
pelargonium.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 30 drops 3x daily or as directed.

pennyroyal.description: A mint-family herb historically used as an emmenagogue. HIGHLY TOXIC.
pennyroyal.safetyClassification: HIGHLY TOXIC - causes liver failure, death; NEVER use internally; avoid in pregnancy
pennyroyal.dosageGuidelines: NOT RECOMMENDED for internal use. External insect repellent only with caution.

peppermint.description: A cooling herb used for digestion, headaches, and respiratory complaints.
peppermint.usages: IBS, nausea, headaches, colds, bad breath, muscle pain
peppermint.activeConstituents: Menthol, menthone, menthyl acetate, rosmarinic acid
peppermint.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may worsen GERD; avoid in infants (menthol)
peppermint.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g dried leaf. Oil capsules: 0.2-0.4ml enteric-coated for IBS.

periwinkle.description: A source of vincristine/vinblastine used in cancer treatment. TOXIC.
periwinkle.safetyClassification: TOXIC - pharmaceutical use only; do not self-medicate
periwinkle.dosageGuidelines: Pharmaceutical preparations only under medical supervision.

pine.description: Pine needles and bark used for respiratory health and antioxidant support.
pine.usages: Coughs, colds, UTIs, circulation (bark extract), antioxidant
pine.safetyClassification: Generally safe; some species toxic; avoid in pregnancy

plantain.description: A common weed used for wound healing, bites, and respiratory complaints.
plantain.usages: Wounds, insect bites, coughs, diarrhea, UTIs
plantain.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals
plantain.dosageGuidelines: Fresh leaf: poultice for wounds. Tea: 2-4g dried. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

poke root.description: A powerful lymphatic herb. TOXIC - requires professional guidance.
poke root.usages: Lymphatic congestion, mastitis, tonsillitis, skin conditions
poke root.safetyClassification: TOXIC - professional use only; never use fresh; avoid in pregnancy
poke root.dosageGuidelines: Professional supervision required. Dried root tincture: 1-5 drops only.

pomegranate.description: A fruit with powerful antioxidant and cardiovascular benefits.
pomegranate.usages: Heart health, prostate health, parasites, diarrhea, inflammation
pomegranate.activeConstituents: Punicalagins, ellagic acid, anthocyanins, punicic acid
pomegranate.safetyClassification: Fruit/juice safe; bark/root may interact with medications

propolis.description: Bee glue, a resinous substance with antimicrobial and immune properties.
propolis.usages: Infections, wound healing, oral health, immune support, cold sores
propolis.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause allergic reactions in bee-sensitive individuals

psyllium.description: A bulk-forming fiber used for constipation and cholesterol management.
psyllium.usages: Constipation, diarrhea, IBS, high cholesterol, blood sugar
psyllium.safetyClassification: Take with plenty of water; may cause choking; take separately from medications
psyllium.dosageGuidelines: Husk: 5-10g daily with 240ml water per 5g. Start low, increase gradually.

pumpkin seed.description: A nutritive seed used for prostate health and parasites.
pumpkin seed.usages: BPH, bladder health, parasites, anxiety, nutrition
pumpkin seed.activeConstituents: Cucurbitin, phytosterols, zinc, omega fatty acids
pumpkin seed.dosageGuidelines: Seeds: 10-30g daily. Oil: 1-2 tsp daily. Extract: 160-480mg daily.

pygeum.description: An African bark used for prostate health and urinary complaints.
pygeum.usages: BPH, prostatitis, urinary symptoms, male fertility
pygeum.activeConstituents: Phytosterols, pentacyclic triterpenes, ferulic acid esters
pygeum.safetyClassification: Generally safe; endangered species - use sustainably sourced

raspberry leaf.description: A uterine tonic traditionally used to prepare for childbirth.
raspberry leaf.ml: Uterine tonic, astringent, nutritive, partus preparator
raspberry leaf.usages: Pregnancy preparation, menstrual cramps, diarrhea, sore throat
raspberry leaf.safetyClassification: Generally safe in pregnancy (2nd/3rd trimester); consult practitioner
raspberry leaf.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried leaf 2-3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

red clover.description: A blood-purifying herb with phytoestrogens for menopausal support.
red clover.usages: Menopause, skin conditions, coughs, lymphatic congestion
red clover.safetyClassification: Avoid in hormone-sensitive conditions; may interact with blood thinners
red clover.dosageGuidelines: Dried flowers: 2-4g as tea. Standardized extract: 40-160mg isoflavones daily.

rehmannia.description: Di Huang, a TCM blood and yin tonic used for kidney and liver support.
rehmannia.ml: Blood tonic, yin tonic, anti-inflammatory, hypoglycemic
rehmannia.usages: Anemia, menstrual disorders, diabetes, kidney/liver support, aging
rehmannia.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause digestive upset; use prepared form for tonifying
rehmannia.dosageGuidelines: Prepared root: 9-30g in decoction. Raw: for clearing heat. Usually in formulas.

reishi.description: The mushroom of immortality, used for immune support and longevity.
reishi.usages: Immune support, stress, insomnia, liver protection, cancer support
reishi.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with anticoagulants, immunosuppressants

rhodiola.description: Arctic root, an adaptogen for stress, fatigue, and mental performance.
rhodiola.usages: Stress, fatigue, depression, cognitive function, athletic performance
rhodiola.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause insomnia if taken late; avoid in bipolar disorder

rhubarb.description: A laxative root used in TCM for constipation and blood stasis.
rhubarb.usages: Constipation, jaundice, fever, blood stasis, skin conditions
rhubarb.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, IBD, kidney disease; short-term use only; leaves toxic
rhubarb.dosageGuidelines: Root: 0.5-2g for laxative. Lower doses (0.1-0.3g) are astringent.

rose.description: A gentle flower used for emotional support, skin care, and digestion.
rose.usages: Anxiety, grief, skin care, sore throat, menstrual support
rose.activeConstituents: Geraniol, citronellol, tannins, flavonoids, vitamin C (hips)
rose.safetyClassification: Generally safe; ensure organic/unsprayed for internal use
rose.dosageGuidelines: Petals: 1-2g as tea. Rose hip: 2-5g. Essential oil: diluted topically.

rosemary.description: An aromatic herb used for memory, circulation, and digestion.
rosemary.usages: Memory, concentration, digestion, headaches, hair growth, circulation
rosemary.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid large doses in pregnancy, epilepsy
rosemary.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Essential oil: diluted topically.

rue.description: A bitter herb historically used as an emmenagogue and antispasmodic. TOXIC.
rue.usages: Historical: menstrual regulation, eye strain, spasms
rue.safetyClassification: TOXIC - causes severe photosensitivity, abortion; avoid in pregnancy; professional only
rue.dosageGuidelines: Not recommended for self-use. Professional guidance required.

saffron.description: The world's most expensive spice, used for mood, cognition, and as a coloring agent.
saffron.usages: Depression, PMS, memory, libido, eye health
saffron.safetyClassification: Generally safe in culinary amounts; high doses (>5g) toxic; avoid in pregnancy
saffron.dosageGuidelines: Culinary: pinch. Medicinal: 15-30mg daily. Max 1.5g daily.

sage.description: A culinary herb used for memory, menopausal sweats, and sore throats.
sage.usages: Hot flashes, excessive sweating, sore throat, memory, digestion
sage.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy, epilepsy; contains thujone - avoid long-term high doses
sage.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-3g dried leaf. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Gargle: strong tea.

sandalwood.description: A fragrant wood used for meditation, skin care, and urinary complaints.
sandalwood.usages: Meditation, anxiety, UTIs, skin conditions, libido
sandalwood.safetyClassification: Generally safe; endangered - use sustainably sourced; may cause skin sensitization
sandalwood.dosageGuidelines: Essential oil: 1-2 drops diluted. Internal: not commonly recommended.

sarsaparilla.description: A root used for skin conditions, hormonal support, and as a blood purifier.
sarsaparilla.usages: Skin conditions, psoriasis, arthritis, hormonal support, detoxification
sarsaparilla.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with digitalis and bismuth

sassafras.description: A root bark historically used for blood purification. Contains carcinogenic safrole.
sassafras.usages: Historical: spring tonic, skin conditions, arthritis
sassafras.safetyClassification: BANNED for internal use in many countries due to safrole; carcinogenic
sassafras.dosageGuidelines: Not recommended. Safrole-free extracts only if available.

saw palmetto.description: A palm berry used for prostate health and urinary symptoms.
saw palmetto.usages: BPH, prostatitis, urinary symptoms, hair loss
saw palmetto.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with hormone therapies, anticoagulants
saw palmetto.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 160mg twice daily or 320mg once daily.

schisandra.description: Five-flavor berry, a TCM adaptogen for liver, stress, and endurance.
schisandra.usages: Stress, fatigue, liver protection, mental performance, respiratory health
schisandra.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with CYP-metabolized medications
schisandra.dosageGuidelines: Dried berries: 1-3g daily. Standardized extract: 500-1000mg daily.

sea buckthorn.description: A nutrient-dense berry used for skin, mucous membranes, and cardiovascular health.
sea buckthorn.usages: Skin health, mucous membrane healing, cardiovascular support, radiation protection
sea buckthorn.activeConstituents: Omega-7 (palmitoleic acid), vitamins C and E, carotenoids, flavonoids
sea buckthorn.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may slow blood clotting
sea buckthorn.dosageGuidelines: Berry oil: 1-2g daily. Seed oil: 1-2g daily. Juice: 20-30ml daily.

senna.description: A powerful stimulant laxative for short-term constipation relief.
senna.activeConstituents: Sennosides A and B, anthraquinones, flavonoids
senna.safetyClassification: Short-term use only (1-2 weeks); avoid in pregnancy, IBD, children under 12

shatavari.description: The queen of herbs in Ayurveda, a female reproductive tonic.
shatavari.usages: Female fertility, menopause, lactation, digestive health, immune support
shatavari.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid in estrogen-sensitive conditions; may cause weight gain
shatavari.dosageGuidelines: Root powder: 3-6g daily. Decoction: 50-100ml twice daily.

sheep sorrel.description: A sour herb used in Essiac formula for cancer support and as a diuretic.
sheep sorrel.usages: Cancer support (Essiac), fever, inflammation, skin conditions
sheep sorrel.activeConstituents: Oxalic acid, anthraquinones, flavonoids, vitamin C
sheep sorrel.safetyClassification: High oxalate content - avoid in kidney stones, kidney disease; avoid large amounts
sheep sorrel.dosageGuidelines: Usually in formulas (Essiac). Fresh: small amounts as food.

shepherd's purse.description: A hemostatic herb used for heavy menstrual bleeding and wound healing.
shepherd's purse.usages: Heavy menstrual bleeding, postpartum hemorrhage, nosebleeds, UTIs
shepherd's purse.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy (uterine stimulant); avoid with heart conditions, thyroid disorders
shepherd's purse.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

shiitake.description: A culinary mushroom with immune-modulating and cardiovascular benefits.
shiitake.usages: Immune support, cholesterol, cancer support, liver health
shiitake.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause dermatitis (shiitake flagellate) in some

skullcap.description: A nervine herb used for anxiety, insomnia, and nervous tension.
skullcap.usages: Anxiety, insomnia, nervous tension, withdrawal support, inflammation (Chinese)
skullcap.safetyClassification: Generally safe; rare liver toxicity reported (possibly adulteration)
skullcap.dosageGuidelines: American: 1-2g dried herb or 2-4ml tincture 3x daily. Chinese: 3-9g in decoction.

slippery elm.description: A soothing bark used for digestive and respiratory irritation.
slippery elm.usages: Sore throat, coughs, gastritis, ulcers, IBS, wound healing
slippery elm.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may slow absorption of medications; endangered - use sustainably
slippery elm.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 1-4g mixed with water. Lozenges: as directed. Take separately from medications.

solomon's seal.description: A root used for musculoskeletal injuries and connective tissue repair.
solomon's seal.usages: Joint injuries, tendon/ligament repair, dry coughs, digestive irritation
solomon's seal.safetyClassification: Generally safe; berries toxic; avoid in pregnancy

spearmint.description: A milder mint used for digestion and as an anti-androgen for hirsutism.
spearmint.usages: Digestion, nausea, hirsutism, PCOS, bad breath
spearmint.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may reduce androgens - caution in men
spearmint.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g dried leaf 2x daily. For hirsutism: 2 cups daily.

spirulina.description: A blue-green algae used as a nutrient-dense superfood.
spirulina.usages: Nutrition, immune support, allergies, heavy metal detox, energy
spirulina.activeConstituents: Phycocyanin, chlorophyll, protein, vitamins, minerals, GLA
spirulina.safetyClassification: Generally safe; source quality important (contamination risk); avoid in autoimmune conditions

st. john's wort.description: A mood-lifting herb used for mild-moderate depression and nerve pain.
st. john's wort.usages: Depression, anxiety, nerve pain, wound healing, viral infections
st. john's wort.safetyClassification: MANY DRUG INTERACTIONS (CYP3A4 inducer); photosensitizing; avoid with SSRIs, birth control
st. john's wort.dosageGuidelines: Standardized extract: 300mg 3x daily (0.3% hypericin). Allow 4-6 weeks for effect.

stevia.description: A natural zero-calorie sweetener from South America.
stevia.usages: Sugar substitute, diabetes support, blood pressure
stevia.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may lower blood sugar and blood pressure
stevia.dosageGuidelines: Leaf: as sweetener. Extract: as directed on product.

stinging nettle.description: See 'nettle' - same plant, referring to the stinging hairs on fresh leaves.
stinging nettle.usages: Allergies, BPH, arthritis, anemia, kidney support
