stinging nettle.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with blood thinners, diabetes medications
stinging nettle.dosageGuidelines: Leaf tea: 2-4g 3x daily. Root: 300-600mg daily for prostate.

suma.description: Brazilian ginseng, an adaptogen used for energy and immune support.
suma.usages: Fatigue, stress, immune support, athletic performance, libido

sweet annie.description: See 'artemisia annua' - sweet wormwood, source of artemisinin.
sweet annie.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 5-9g dried herb per liter, divided doses.

tea tree.description: An Australian essential oil used topically for infections and skin conditions.
tea tree.usages: Acne, fungal infections, wounds, dandruff, insect bites
tea tree.safetyClassification: EXTERNAL USE ONLY; toxic if ingested; may cause skin sensitization

thyme.description: A culinary herb with powerful antimicrobial and expectorant properties.
thyme.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, sore throat, digestive complaints, infections
thyme.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid large doses in pregnancy; essential oil potent
thyme.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 1-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Essential oil: diluted topically.

tribulus.description: A spiny plant used for libido, athletic performance, and urinary health.
tribulus.usages: Libido, erectile dysfunction, athletic performance, urinary stones
tribulus.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may affect hormone levels; avoid in hormone-sensitive conditions

triphala.description: An Ayurvedic formula of three fruits (amalaki, bibhitaki, haritaki) for digestion.
triphala.scientificName: Phyllanthus emblica, Terminalia bellirica, Terminalia chebula
triphala.usages: Constipation, digestion, detoxification, eye health, longevity
triphala.activeConstituents: Tannins, gallic acid, chebulic acid, vitamin C
triphala.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause loose stools initially; avoid in pregnancy, diarrhea
triphala.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 3-6g daily, usually at bedtime with warm water.

tulsi.description: See 'holy basil' - sacred adaptogenic herb in Ayurveda.
tulsi.usages: Stress, anxiety, respiratory infections, blood sugar
tulsi.activeConstituents: Eugenol, rosmarinic acid, ursolic acid, ocimumosides
tulsi.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may have blood-thinning effects

turmeric.description: A golden spice with powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
turmeric.usages: Inflammation, arthritis, digestive complaints, liver support, skin conditions
turmeric.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may interact with blood thinners; avoid with gallstones
turmeric.dosageGuidelines: Powder: 1-3g daily with black pepper/fat. Curcumin extract: 500-2000mg daily.

usnea.description: Old man's beard lichen, used for respiratory and urinary infections.
usnea.usages: Respiratory infections, UTIs, strep throat, wound healing
usnea.safetyClassification: Generally safe short-term; usnic acid may be hepatotoxic in high doses

uva ursi.safetyClassification: Short-term use only (1-2 weeks); avoid in pregnancy, kidney disease
uva ursi.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 3-12g daily divided. Extract: 400-800mg arbutin daily.

valerian.description: A sedative root used for insomnia and anxiety.
valerian.usages: Insomnia, anxiety, nervous tension, muscle spasms
valerian.activeConstituents: Valerenic acid, isovaleric acid, iridoids, GABA
valerian.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause paradoxical stimulation in some; avoid with sedatives
valerian.dosageGuidelines: Root: 2-3g as tea before bed. Standardized extract: 300-600mg before bed.

vanilla.description: A fragrant orchid pod used as flavoring and mild nervine.

vervain.description: A nervine herb used for stress, tension headaches, and liver support.
vervain.usages: Stress, anxiety, tension headaches, depression, liver support
vervain.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy (uterine stimulant); may interact with hormone therapies
vervain.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

vitex.description: See 'chaste tree' - hormone-balancing herb for women's health.

white oak.description: An astringent bark used for diarrhea, bleeding, and skin conditions.
white oak.usages: Diarrhea, hemorrhoids, bleeding gums, skin conditions, sore throat
white oak.safetyClassification: Generally safe externally; internal use may cause constipation, GI upset
white oak.dosageGuidelines: Bark decoction: 1-2g. Gargle/wash: as prepared. Internal: short-term only.

white willow.description: The original source of aspirin, used for pain and inflammation.
white willow.usages: Pain, fever, headaches, arthritis, back pain
white willow.safetyClassification: Avoid with aspirin allergy; avoid in children with viral infections (Reye's risk)
white willow.dosageGuidelines: Bark: 1-3g as decoction. Standardized extract: 120-240mg salicin daily.

wild cherry.description: A bark used for coughs and respiratory complaints.
wild cherry.usages: Dry coughs, bronchitis, whooping cough, digestive complaints
wild cherry.safetyClassification: Contains cyanogenic glycosides - use prepared bark only; avoid in pregnancy
wild cherry.dosageGuidelines: Bark syrup: as directed. Tea: 1-2g dried bark. Short-term use.

wild yam.description: A root historically used for menstrual cramps and menopausal symptoms.
wild yam.usages: Menstrual cramps, menopausal symptoms, digestive spasms
wild yam.safetyClassification: Generally safe; diosgenin is NOT converted to hormones in the body

witch hazel.description: An astringent shrub used topically for skin conditions and hemorrhoids.
witch hazel.usages: Hemorrhoids, varicose veins, bruises, acne, skin irritation
witch hazel.activeConstituents: Hamamelitannin, gallic acid, catechins, essential oil
witch hazel.safetyClassification: External use generally safe; internal use may cause GI upset
witch hazel.dosageGuidelines: Topical: distillate or decoction as needed. Internal: 2-4ml tincture (rare).

wood betony.description: See 'betony' - nervine herb for headaches and anxiety.
wood betony.usages: Headaches, anxiety, poor digestion, wound healing
wood betony.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; generally safe otherwise

wormwood.description: See 'absinthe herb' - bitter herb used for digestion and parasites.
wormwood.safetyClassification: Contains neurotoxic thujone; avoid in pregnancy; short-term use only
wormwood.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2g dried herb. Tincture: 10-20 drops before meals.

yarrow.description: A wound-healing herb used for bleeding, fever, and digestive complaints.
yarrow.usages: Wounds, heavy menstrual bleeding, fever, colds, digestive complaints
yarrow.safetyClassification: Avoid in pregnancy; may cause allergic reactions in Asteraceae-sensitive individuals
yarrow.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Topical: as poultice.

yellow dock.description: A bitter root used for constipation, skin conditions, and iron deficiency.
yellow dock.usages: Constipation, skin conditions, anemia, liver support
yellow dock.safetyClassification: Contains oxalates - avoid in kidney stones; avoid in pregnancy

yerba mate.description: A South American stimulant tea used for energy and weight management.
yerba mate.usages: Fatigue, weight management, mental clarity, depression
yerba mate.safetyClassification: Contains caffeine; hot consumption linked to esophageal cancer risk
yerba mate.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 3-5g per cup. Avoid very hot temperatures.

yerba santa.description: A California herb used for respiratory conditions and as an expectorant.
yerba santa.dosageGuidelines: Dried leaf: 2-4g as tea. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

yohimbe.description: An African bark used for erectile dysfunction. Potent and potentially dangerous.
yohimbe.safetyClassification: DANGEROUS - causes hypertension, anxiety, tachycardia; many drug interactions; prescription in some countries
yohimbe.dosageGuidelines: Professional supervision required. Standardized yohimbine: 5-10mg under medical guidance.

yucca.description: A desert plant used for arthritis and inflammation.
yucca.usages: Arthritis, joint pain, inflammation, digestive complaints
yucca.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause GI upset; may affect nutrient absorption

burnet saxifrage.description: A European herb with aromatic roots used for respiratory and digestive complaints. The root has a warm, peppery taste.
burnet saxifrage.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, sore throat, digestive complaints, urinary tract
burnet saxifrage.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid during pregnancy; may cause photosensitivity
burnet saxifrage.dosageGuidelines: Root decoction: 1-2g in 150ml water, 2-3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

calamint.description: An aromatic mint-family herb with a pleasant minty-oregano scent, traditionally used for digestive and respiratory complaints.
calamint.usages: Digestive complaints, colds, fevers, nervous tension, insomnia
calamint.safetyClassification: Avoid during pregnancy (contains pulegone); use in moderation
calamint.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2 tsp dried herb per cup, 2-3x daily. Not for long-term use.

cretan dittany.description: A rare aromatic herb endemic to Crete, prized since antiquity for wound healing and as a digestive tonic. Also called Dittany of Crete.
cretan dittany.usages: Wound healing, digestive complaints, menstrual regulation, colds
cretan dittany.safetyClassification: Avoid during pregnancy; generally safe in culinary amounts
cretan dittany.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1 tsp dried herb per cup, 1-2x daily. External: as poultice or infused oil.

elderflower.description: The fragrant white flowers of the elder tree, traditionally used for colds, flu, and fever. A gentle remedy suitable for children.
elderflower.usages: Colds, flu, fever, sinusitis, hay fever, skin conditions
elderflower.activeConstituents: Flavonoids (rutin, quercetin), phenolic acids, triterpenes, mucilage
elderflower.safetyClassification: Generally safe; flowers are safe raw; other plant parts require cooking
elderflower.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried flowers per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

fig.description: A sweet Mediterranean fruit used medicinally as a gentle laxative and demulcent. The latex has traditional uses for warts.
fig.usages: Constipation, sore throat, coughs, skin conditions, warts
fig.safetyClassification: Generally safe; latex may cause skin irritation; avoid latex during pregnancy
fig.dosageGuidelines: Dried figs: 3-5 daily for constipation. Syrup: 1-2 tbsp as needed.

forest woundwort.description: A woodland herb traditionally used to stop bleeding and heal wounds. Also known as hedge woundwort or wood betony relative.
forest woundwort.usages: Wound healing, bleeding, joint pain, cramps
forest woundwort.safetyClassification: Generally safe for external use; limited internal use data
forest woundwort.dosageGuidelines: External: fresh leaf poultice or infused oil. Tea: 1-2 tsp per cup, 2x daily.

goldenrod.description: A bright yellow flowering herb excellent for urinary tract health and kidney support. Traditionally used as a diuretic and anti-inflammatory.
goldenrod.usages: Urinary tract infections, kidney stones, arthritis, allergies
goldenrod.activeConstituents: Saponins, flavonoids (rutin, quercetin), phenolic acids, tannins
goldenrod.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid with kidney disease; may cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to Asteraceae
goldenrod.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

gum arabic.description: A natural gum from acacia trees used as a binder, emulsifier, and demulcent. Also known as acacia gum.
gum arabic.usages: Sore throat, coughs, digestive coating, pharmaceutical binder
gum arabic.safetyClassification: Generally recognized as safe (GRAS); rare allergic reactions
gum arabic.dosageGuidelines: As demulcent: 1-2g dissolved in water. As binder: per formulation needs.

hedge mustard.description: A traditional singer's herb used for hoarseness and loss of voice. Known as the 'singer's plant' in European folk medicine.
hedge mustard.usages: Hoarseness, laryngitis, coughs, bronchitis, sore throat
hedge mustard.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid large doses during pregnancy
hedge mustard.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2 tsp dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Fresh juice: 1-2 tbsp daily.

icelandic moss.description: A lichen (not a true moss) from northern regions, traditionally used for respiratory and digestive complaints. Rich in mucilage.
icelandic moss.usages: Coughs, bronchitis, sore throat, digestive weakness, loss of appetite
icelandic moss.activeConstituents: Lichenin, isolichenin, usnic acid, bitter acids (cetraric acid)
icelandic moss.safetyClassification: Generally safe; soak to remove bitter acids if desired
icelandic moss.dosageGuidelines: Decoction: 1-2 tsp per cup, simmer 10-15 min, 2-3x daily. Lozenges as directed.

larch.description: A deciduous conifer whose resin (Venice turpentine) and bark have traditional medicinal uses for respiratory and skin conditions.
larch.usages: Respiratory congestion, wounds, skin conditions, rheumatism
larch.safetyClassification: External use generally safe; resin may cause skin sensitization; internal use requires caution
larch.dosageGuidelines: Arabinogalactan: 1-3g daily. External: diluted resin preparations as directed.

oak gall.description: Abnormal growths on oak trees caused by wasp larvae, extremely rich in tannins. Used traditionally as a powerful astringent.
oak gall.usages: Hemorrhoids, diarrhea, bleeding gums, wounds, skin conditions
oak gall.safetyClassification: External use generally safe; internal use in small amounts only; may cause constipation
oak gall.dosageGuidelines: External: decoction for washes/compresses. Internal: very small doses only, under guidance.

oatmeal.description: Ground oats used externally as a soothing, anti-itch treatment for skin conditions. Colloidal oatmeal is particularly effective.
oatmeal.usages: Eczema, dry skin, itching, rashes, chickenpox, sunburn
oatmeal.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid if allergic to oats or gluten-sensitive (for internal use)
oatmeal.dosageGuidelines: Bath: 1-2 cups colloidal oatmeal per bath. Poultice: as needed for skin.

wild pansy.description: A delicate wildflower also called heartsease, traditionally used for skin conditions and respiratory complaints in children.
wild pansy.usages: Eczema, cradle cap, acne, coughs, bronchitis, rheumatism
wild pansy.safetyClassification: Generally safe; suitable for children; avoid very high doses
wild pansy.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2 tsp dried herb per cup, 3x daily. External: as wash or compress.

pellitory of the wall.description: A small herb growing on walls and rocks, traditionally used as a powerful diuretic for urinary and kidney complaints.
pellitory of the wall.usages: Urinary tract infections, kidney stones, cystitis, edema
pellitory of the wall.activeConstituents: Flavonoids, potassium salts, mucilage, tannins, sulfur compounds
pellitory of the wall.safetyClassification: Generally safe; may cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to Urticaceae; avoid with kidney disease
pellitory of the wall.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Fresh juice: 1-2 tbsp 3x daily.

red poppy.description: The common corn poppy with bright red petals, a gentle sedative traditionally used for coughs and sleep. Much milder than opium poppy.
red poppy.usages: Coughs, insomnia, anxiety, irritability in children
red poppy.safetyClassification: Generally safe in normal doses; much milder than opium poppy; avoid during pregnancy
red poppy.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2 tsp dried petals per cup, 1-2x daily. Syrup: 1-2 tsp as needed.

reindeer moss.description: A lichen from arctic and subarctic regions, similar to Icelandic moss, used for respiratory and digestive complaints.
reindeer moss.safetyClassification: Generally safe; soak to remove bitter acids; similar cautions to Icelandic moss
reindeer moss.dosageGuidelines: Decoction: 1-2 tsp per cup after soaking, 2-3x daily.

rest harrow.description: A spiny legume with pink flowers, traditionally used as a diuretic for urinary complaints and gout.
rest harrow.usages: Urinary tract infections, kidney stones, gout, rheumatism, edema
rest harrow.safetyClassification: Generally safe; avoid with severe kidney disease; may interact with diuretics
rest harrow.dosageGuidelines: Root decoction: 2-4g per cup, 2-3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

cloudberry.description: An arctic berry rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, traditionally used by Nordic peoples for scurvy prevention and general health.
cloudberry.usages: Vitamin C deficiency, general health, fever, urinary complaints
cloudberry.dosageGuidelines: Fresh berries: as food. Leaf tea: 1-2 tsp per cup, 2-3x daily.

silverweed.description: A creeping herb with silvery leaves, traditionally used for digestive cramps and diarrhea. Also known as goosewort.
silverweed.usages: Diarrhea, menstrual cramps, digestive spasms, sore throat, bleeding gums
silverweed.activeConstituents: Tannins (up to 10%), flavonoids, choline, bitter compounds
silverweed.safetyClassification: Generally safe; high tannin content may cause stomach upset in sensitive individuals
silverweed.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 2-4g dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

sloe.description: The small, tart fruit of the blackthorn bush, traditionally used for digestive complaints and as an astringent. Used to make sloe gin.
sloe.usages: Diarrhea, mouth inflammation, sore throat, digestive tonic
sloe.activeConstituents: Tannins, flavonoids, anthocyanins, organic acids, vitamin C
sloe.safetyClassification: Generally safe; seeds contain amygdalin (do not crush/consume seeds)
sloe.dosageGuidelines: Berries: as food/preserve after frost. Flower tea: 1-2 tsp per cup, 2-3x daily.

spelt.description: An ancient grain favored by Hildegard of Bingen as the ideal food for health. Considered more digestible than modern wheat.
spelt.activeConstituents: Complex carbohydrates, protein, B vitamins, minerals, fiber
spelt.safetyClassification: Contains gluten; avoid with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity
spelt.dosageGuidelines: As food: incorporate into diet as grain, flour, or bread.

stonecrop.description: A succulent plant traditionally used externally for burns, wounds, and skin conditions. Also known as wall pepper or biting stonecrop.
stonecrop.ml: Vulnerary, astringent, rubefacient, emetic (in large doses)
stonecrop.safetyClassification: External use only recommended; internal use can cause vomiting and irritation
stonecrop.dosageGuidelines: External: fresh plant juice or poultice applied to affected area.

thuja.description: An evergreen tree whose leaves have traditional uses for warts and respiratory conditions. Also known as arbor vitae (tree of life).
thuja.usages: Warts, respiratory infections, urinary tract infections
thuja.safetyClassification: CAUTION: Contains thujone which is toxic in large amounts; avoid during pregnancy; use only under professional guidance
thuja.dosageGuidelines: Homeopathic preparations preferred. Tincture: only under professional guidance, very low doses.

tormentil.description: A small herb with four-petaled yellow flowers, one of the most astringent European herbs. Excellent for diarrhea and mouth inflammations.
tormentil.usages: Diarrhea, dysentery, mouth ulcers, sore throat, bleeding gums, wounds
tormentil.safetyClassification: Generally safe; very high tannin content may cause stomach upset; avoid with constipation
tormentil.dosageGuidelines: Root decoction: 2-4g per cup, 3x daily. Tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily. Gargle: as needed.

white poplar.description: A tree whose buds and bark contain salicin, a natural aspirin-like compound. Traditionally used for pain and fever.
white poplar.usages: Pain, fever, arthritis, rheumatism, urinary complaints
white poplar.safetyClassification: Avoid if allergic to aspirin; avoid during pregnancy; may interact with blood thinners
white poplar.dosageGuidelines: Bark decoction: 1-2g per cup, 2-3x daily. Bud tincture: 2-4ml 3x daily.

wild lettuce.description: A tall lettuce relative with milky sap, traditionally used as a mild sedative and pain reliever. Sometimes called lettuce opium.
wild lettuce.safetyClassification: Use with caution; may cause drowsiness; avoid during pregnancy; avoid with glaucoma
wild lettuce.dosageGuidelines: Dried herb tea: 1-2g per cup at bedtime. Tincture: 2-4ml at bedtime.

black hellebore.description: A highly toxic plant historically used in very small doses as a purgative and heart stimulant. Also known as Christmas Rose. EXTREMELY DANGEROUS.
black hellebore.usages: Historical: dropsy, heart conditions, melancholy, worms. NOT FOR MODERN USE.
black hellebore.safetyClassification: EXTREMELY TOXIC - All parts poisonous. Can cause fatal cardiac arrest. Historical use only. DO NOT USE.
black hellebore.dosageGuidelines: NOT RECOMMENDED. Historical preparations used minute doses under strict supervision. Modern use is contraindicated.

marsh tea.description: Also known as wild rosemary or Labrador tea, a strongly aromatic bog plant used historically as a powerful sedative and expectorant. Contains toxic volatile oils.
marsh tea.usages: Whooping cough, bronchitis, insomnia, rheumatism, insect repellent
marsh tea.safetyClassification: CAUTION: Contains neurotoxic volatile oils (ledol). Use only in micro-doses under expert guidance. Contraindicated in pregnancy and children.
marsh tea.dosageGuidelines: Tincture: 3-5 drops maximum, 1-2x daily. Tea: NOT recommended due to toxicity. Historical use only.

water mint.description: A wild mint species found near water, milder than peppermint. Used traditionally for digestive complaints and headaches.
water mint.safetyClassification: Generally safe in moderate amounts. Contains pulegone - avoid large doses during pregnancy.
water mint.dosageGuidelines: Tea: 1-2 tsp dried herb per cup, 3x daily. Oil: 5-10 drops internally or topically for headaches.

earthworm.description: Earthworms (Lumbricus terrestris) have been used in traditional European and Chinese medicine for circulatory disorders and wound healing. Known as Di Long in TCM.
earthworm.usages: Fever, convulsions, stroke recovery, circulatory disorders, wound healing, asthma
earthworm.activeConstituents: Lumbrokinase (fibrinolytic enzyme), lumbrofebrine, hypoxanthine, amino acids
earthworm.safetyClassification: Use only properly prepared/processed products. Raw earthworms may carry parasites. Avoid with bleeding disorders or anticoagulant use.
earthworm.dosageGuidelines: Dried powder: 1-3g daily. Extract: as directed on product. Traditional: processed and dried before use.

hemp agrimony.description: A tall European herb (also called holy rope) traditionally used to support fevers, colds, and sluggish lymph. Historically used as a cleansing, sweat-promoting herb.
hemp agrimony.usages: Feverish colds, influenza support, lymphatic congestion, skin eruptions (traditional)
hemp agrimony.activeConstituents: Sesquiterpene lactones (eupatoriopicrin), flavonoids, tannins, pyrrolizidine alkaloids (trace)
hemp agrimony.safetyClassification: CAUTION: Potential pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PA) concern; avoid long-term internal use, pregnancy, breastfeeding, and liver disease.
hemp agrimony.dosageGuidelines: Tea (short-term): 1-2g dried herb per cup, 1-2x daily for a few days. Tincture: 1-2ml, 1-2x daily short-term.

alcohol.description: Ethanol used in herbal medicine primarily as a solvent and preservative for tinctures and extracts. The percentage determines what constituents are best extracted.
alcohol.usages: Tincture menstruum (extraction solvent), preservative; external antiseptic in formulations
alcohol.safetyClassification: CAUTION: Intoxicating and flammable. Avoid during pregnancy, in liver disease, or with alcohol-use disorder. Interacts with sedatives and many medications.
alcohol.dosageGuidelines: As tincture solvent: varies by formula. If ingesting tinctures, follow dosing for the herb; consider alcohol-free alternatives if needed.

olive.description: Olive oil is a traditional culinary and medicinal oil used as an emollient base for salves and infused oils, and internally for digestive and cardiovascular support.
olive.usages: Carrier oil for salves/infusions, skin barrier support, mild laxative effect (traditional), culinary fat
olive.activeConstituents: Oleic acid, squalene, vitamin E, polyphenols (oleuropein/tyrosol derivatives)
olive.safetyClassification: Generally safe. Rare allergy. Use caution on acne-prone skin (may be comedogenic for some).
olive.dosageGuidelines: Internal (food): 1-2 tbsp daily as tolerated. External: as needed as carrier oil or in formulations.

mullein flower oil.description: An infused oil made from mullein flowers (Verbascum thapsus), traditionally used topically—especially for ear discomfort and inflammation.
mullein flower oil.usages: Ear discomfort (traditional use), soothing inflamed tissue (topical), carrier in salves
mullein flower oil.activeConstituents: Mucilage, flavonoids, iridoid glycosides (extracted into oil in small amounts)
mullein flower oil.safetyClassification: EXTERNAL USE ONLY. Do not use in the ear if the eardrum may be perforated. Discontinue if irritation occurs.
mullein flower oil.dosageGuidelines: Topical: apply a small amount as directed. For ear use: traditional use is warmed drops—only under appropriate guidance and never with suspected perforation.
